dataset.title: Fine Root Biomass on North Hog Chronosequence, Virginia Coast Reserve, 1991-1992

abstract.para: A sequential coring method was used to determine live fine-root biomass (LFRB) along a barrier island dune and swale chronosequence on Hog Island, VA, between February 1991 and February 1992.

section.title: Related Documents
section.para: Stevenson, M. and F.P. Day. 1996. Fine root biomass distribution and production along a barrier island chronosequence. American Midland Naturalist. 135:205-217.

Mark J. Stevenson. 1994. Fine root biomass distribution and production along a barrier island chronosequence. M.S. Thesis, Old Dominion University. URL=http://www.vcrlter.virginia.edu/thesis/Stevenson95.pdf

para.emphasis: This section contains specific methods for this dataset.

description.para: The sequential coring method was used to obtain soil samples for live fine-root biomass (LFRB) extractions. Ten soil cores were collected in a stratified random fashion each month (February-May, July-August, and December 1991 plus January 1992) from each of the dune and swale sites, except for the 6-yr-old dune and 6-yr-old swale communities which were sampled only three times during the study (February, May, and August 1991). The random samples were taken in a stratified manner from more homogeneous sections of the dune to minimize variability (i.e., blowouts and other unusual features were avoided). A plunger style corer (7 cm diameter by 10 cm length) was used to extract the soil cores. The soil cores were extracted in 10-cm increments down to a depth of 40 cm. Each increment sample was placed in a plastic bag and labeled by date, site location, and depth interval. The soil samples were refrigerated immediately after each sampling trip.

A hydropneumatic root washer was used to separate the roots from the soil. The roots were then hand-sorted into the following four categories: live fine roots and rhizomes (<= 2 mm diam.); big roots and rhizomes (> 2 mm diam.); dead fine roots and rhizomes; and detritus (unrecognizable organic matter). Live roots were identified using the method of Schuurman and Goedewaagen (1971, cited in Bohm 1979) and Powell and Day (1991), i.e., live roots were resilient, flexible, and normally had lateral branches. Color was used as a secondary test. Live roots were sometimes white externally or white internally. Dead roots were inflexible, fragmented or crumbled easily when bent. Dead roots were normally dark externally and internally.

After sorting, the roots were dried at 70 degrees C for 48 hours and weighed. If the fine roots (live of dead) were numerous and hard to separate from other organics in the sample, aliquots were used to break down the sample into a more manageable size. The aliquots were weighed and their mass multiplied by the required ratio to obtain a total biomass estimation for each category.
Bohm, W. 1979. Methods of studying root ssystems. Springer-Verlag, New York, N.Y. 188 p.
Powell, S.W. and F.P. Day. 1991. Root production in four communities in the Great Dismal Swamp. Am. J. Bot., 78:288-297.

project.title: Root decomposition and N dynamics in a chronosequence of communities on Hog Island
